psychmeta Overview

Source: vignettes/overview.Rmd
overview.Rmd

psychmeta is a comprehensive package for computing psychometric meta-analyses, organizing meta-analytic data, conducting follow-up analyses of meta-analytic results (e.g., cumulative meta-analyses, leave-one-out meta-analyses, bootstrapped meta-analyses, and meta-regressions), simulating data impacted by psychometric artifacts, and much more!

This tutorial is meant to introduce you to some of the most critical features of psychmeta and familiarize you with workflows within the package.

A new collection of short vignettes for specific tasks is in progress. For the previous “overview” vignette that has been used as a workshop handout, see Welcome to psychmeta!

Installing and loading psychmeta

Install the official CRAN version of the package:

install.packages("psychmeta")

Or install the GitHub verson (with incremental updates between CRAN releases):

devtools::install_github("psychmeta/psychmeta")

Load the package library:

library(psychmeta)

psychmeta vignettes

The following vignettes show workflows for common tasks in psychmeta:

  • Import and organize meta-analytic data
  • Effect size conversion and sporadic artifact correction
  • Computing meta-analyses
    • Meta-analyzing correlations
    • Meta-analyzing d values
    • Artifact corrections
    • Meta-analyzing other effect sizes (coming soon)
  • Follow-up analyses
    • Sensitivity analyses
      • Publication bias, leave-one-out, bootstrap confidence intervals
    • Moderator analyses
    • Outpur results in Word, PDF, HTML, or Markdown
      • Results tables, bibliographies of included studies
    • Plots

Additional topics:

  • Meta-analysis arguments and options
  • Simulating psychometric data and meta-analyses
  • Composite effect sizes and psychometric artifacts
  • Effect size dependency
  • Matrix regression
  • Multivariate range-restriction correction

Best practices for publishing with psychmeta:

  1. Include your R script in an online supplement.
  2. Include your data table as a CSV in an online supplement.
  3. Cite psychmeta.
    • Please reference our software announcement in Applied Psychological Measurement (Dahlke & Wiernik, 2019).

Bibliography

Dahlke, J. A., & Wiernik, B. M. (2019). psychmeta: an R package for psychometric meta-analysis. Applied Psychological Measurement, 43(5), 415–416. https://doi.org/10.1177/0146621618795933
